elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">The asymmetric unit of KHP taken from the 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K X-ray refinement, showing the links to symmetry related atoms, with ellipsoids shown at the 30% level. Symmetry operators are: (A) [1.5−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>−0.5], (B) [2−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>−0.5], (C) [2−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>+0.5], (D) [0.5+<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>+1, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>+0.5].</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  The asymmetric unit of KHP taken from the 100K X-ray refinement, showing the links to symmetry related atoms, with ellipsoids shown at the 30% level. Symmetry operators are: (A) [1.5-x, y, z-0.5], (B) [2-x, 1-y, z-0.5], (C) [2-x, 1-y, z+0.5], (D) [0.5+x, y+1, z+0.5].

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Difference Fourier maps (<ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">o</ce:inf>−<ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf>) obtained with both neutron (right) and X-ray diffraction (left). The maps were calculated on a plane through atoms C7, O1 and O4 (related by symmetry operator). Note that hydrogen peaks are negative in neutron diffraction.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  Difference Fourier maps (F o-F c) obtained with both neutron (right) and X-ray diffraction (left). The maps were calculated on a plane through atoms C7, O1 and O4 (related by symmetry operator). Note that hydrogen peaks are negative in neutron diffraction.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Potassium hydrogen phthalate has been investigated at several temperatures by both neutron and X-ray single crystal diffraction methods. Previous studies have shown that medium-to-strong hydrogen bonds will frequently undergo changes in the behaviour of the hydrogen atom as temperature is increased. Observed effects include proton migration and disorder over two positions. No evidence for either effect is observed for the short hydrogen bond in potassium hydrogen phthalate between 30 and 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, in either the X-ray or neutron data. In addition to demonstrating the robust nature of the geometry of this interaction with respect to temperature, the study has shown once again that X-ray diffraction coupled with simple Fourier imaging methods can reliably screen such hydrogen bonds.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Potassium hydrogen phthalate has been investigated at several temperatures by both neutron and X-ray single crystal diffraction methods. Previous studies have shown that medium-to-strong hydrogen bonds will frequently undergo changes in the behaviour of the hydrogen atom as temperature is increased. Observed effects include proton migration and disorder over two positions. No evidence for either effect is observed for the short hydrogen bond in potassium hydrogen phthalate between 30 and 300K, in either the X-ray or neutron data. In addition to demonstrating the robust nature of the geometry of this interaction with respect to temperature, the study has shown once again that X-ray diffraction coupled with simple Fourier imaging methods can reliably screen such hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Hydrogen bonding is of longstanding interest to chemists, especially in terms of its effect on intermolecular structure. In addition to its importance as the principal molecular ‘glue’ in many structures, many hydrogen bonded systems also exhibit temperature dependent properties, such as proton migration (observed in some short strong hydrogen bonds, where the O⋯O distance typically lies in the range 2.4–2.55<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å ) or hydrogen atom disorder (usually observed in longer ‘medium strength’ hydrogen bonds). Structures refined from neutron data suggest that these interactions occasionally appear to be close to symmetric, often having elongated D–H covalent bonds and correspondingly shortened H⋯A distances, and that hydrogen atoms in these environments frequently exhibit anisotropic displacement parameters elongated along the hydrogen bond . The question then arises as to whether the truer picture of this interaction is a flattening out of the potential energy well to give a truly symmetric hydrogen bond, or rather that the proton is disordered over two unsymmetrical sites with a low energy barrier between them.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Hydrogen bonding is of longstanding interest to chemists, especially in terms of its effect on intermolecular structure. In addition to its importance as the principal molecular ‘glue' in many structures, many hydrogen bonded systems also exhibit temperature dependent properties, such as proton migration (observed in some short strong hydrogen bonds, where the O⋯O distance typically lies in the range 2.4-2.55Å ) or hydrogen atom disorder (usually observed in longer ‘medium strength' hydrogen bonds). Structures refined from neutron data suggest that these interactions occasionally appear to be close to symmetric, often having elongated D-H covalent bonds and correspondingly shortened H⋯A distances, and that hydrogen atoms in these environments frequently exhibit anisotropic displacement parameters elongated along the hydrogen bond . The question then arises as to whether the truer picture of this interaction is a flattening out of the potential energy well to give a truly symmetric hydrogen bond, or rather that the proton is disordered over two unsymmetrical sites with a low energy barrier between them.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Variable or multiple temperature (multi-T) diffraction studies can frequently help provide extra information on such issues . The use of neutron diffraction to study the position of hydrogen atoms in strongly hydrogen bonded structures is well-established ; exploiting multi-T neutron diffraction can make a significant contribution to unravelling the detail behind the description of the hydrogen bond and the hydrogen atom behaviour in such systems. Notable examples of multi-T neutron diffraction work in this area include studies of the strong intra-molecular hydrogen bond in lithium hydrogen phthalate monohydrate , the strong intermolecular hydrogen bond in the urea–phosphoric acid (UPA) molecular complex  and the medium strength hydrogen bond in benzoic acid and its derivatives . In addition, it has recently been shown that, with care, X-rays can also be used to successfully image the hydrogen atoms in this type of multi-T study . Used in parallel, the two methods can give a great deal of complementary information , enhancing the outputs from either individually. A precise determination of the proton position is made with the neutron study, which can then be compared with the behaviour of the electron density of the hydrogen bond as observed by the X-ray study. The strong complementarity of the two sets of observations in this context has recently been observed for UPA , and has been shown to have relevance for a description of the chemistry of the hydrogen bond.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Variable or multiple temperature (multi-T) diffraction studies can frequently help provide extra information on such issues . The use of neutron diffraction to study the position of hydrogen atoms in strongly hydrogen bonded structures is well-established ; exploiting multi-T neutron diffraction can make a significant contribution to unravelling the detail behind the description of the hydrogen bond and the hydrogen atom behaviour in such systems. Notable examples of multi-T neutron diffraction work in this area include studies of the strong intra-molecular hydrogen bond in lithium hydrogen phthalate monohydrate , the strong intermolecular hydrogen bond in the urea-phosphoric acid (UPA) molecular complex  and the medium strength hydrogen bond in benzoic acid and its derivatives . In addition, it has recently been shown that, with care, X-rays can also be used to successfully image the hydrogen atoms in this type of multi-T study . Used in parallel, the two methods can give a great deal of complementary information , enhancing the outputs from either individually. A precise determination of the proton position is made with the neutron study, which can then be compared with the behaviour of the electron density of the hydrogen bond as observed by the X-ray study. The strong complementarity of the two sets of observations in this context has recently been observed for UPA , and has been shown to have relevance for a description of the chemistry of the hydrogen bond.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The motivation for the present study was to use a combination of neutron and X-ray multi-T diffraction to determine the effect of temperature on the borderline short-to-medium length intermolecular interaction in the title compound (KHP) first observed by Okaya . As recent investigations into benzoic acid have revealed a large degree of temperature dependent hydrogen disorder present within the carboxylic acid dimer unit containing medium strength hydrogen bonding, and proton migration has been observed in the short hydrogen bond of the urea–phosphoric acid molecular complex , it was reasoned that an interesting effect may also occur in the mid-range hydrogen bond of KHP.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The motivation for the present study was to use a combination of neutron and X-ray multi-T diffraction to determine the effect of temperature on the borderline short-to-medium length intermolecular interaction in the title compound (KHP) first observed by Okaya . As recent investigations into benzoic acid have revealed a large degree of temperature dependent hydrogen disorder present within the carboxylic acid dimer unit containing medium strength hydrogen bonding, and proton migration has been observed in the short hydrogen bond of the urea-phosphoric acid molecular complex , it was reasoned that an interesting effect may also occur in the mid-range hydrogen bond of KHP.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Crystals of the title compound suitable for both X-ray and neutron diffraction were grown by slow evaporation from aqueous solution. X-ray datasets were collected at temperatures of 100 and 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K by a series of ω-scans at different <ce:italic>φ</ce:italic>-values on a Bruker SMART-1K CCD Diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), and equipped with an Oxford Cryosystems Cryostream low temperature device. Potassium hydrogen phthalate crystallises in the orthorhombic <ce:italic>Pca</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> space group with <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=4. No absorption corrections were carried out. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS  for the 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K data, and refined using these coordinates for the 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K data. Refinement was performed using SHELXL-97  on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> against all independent reflections by full-matrix least squares. At both temperatures all hydrogen atoms had their positions and isotropic atomic displacement parameters freely refined.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Crystals of the title compound suitable for both X-ray and neutron diffraction were grown by slow evaporation from aqueous solution. X-ray datasets were collected at temperatures of 100 and 300K by a series of ω-scans at different φ-values on a Bruker SMART-1K CCD Diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å), and equipped with an Oxford Cryosystems Cryostream low temperature device. Potassium hydrogen phthalate crystallises in the orthorhombic Pca21 space group with Z=4. No absorption corrections were carried out. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS  for the 100K data, and refined using these coordinates for the 300K data. Refinement was performed using SHELXL-97  on F 2 against all independent reflections by full-matrix least squares. At both temperatures all hydrogen atoms had their positions and isotropic atomic displacement parameters freely refined.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Neutron data were collected on the SXD instrument at the ISIS spallation neutron source , using the time-of-flight Laue diffraction method . This method uses a wavelength-sorted white neutron beam combined with large area position-sensitive detectors to allow a large volume of reciprocal space to be measured in a single crystal setting, or frame. The SXD instrument has 11 position-sensitive detectors giving a solid-angle coverage of over 2π Sr . The full data collection process consists of a series of frames collected with a stationary crystal-detector arrangement. To aid with data collection times and allow data to be accumulated at several temperatures from the rather small crystals available, a multiple crystal sample technique was employed , allowing a full data set to be collected in fewer frames (crystal orientations). In this example four single crystals, each of approximate dimension 1×1×1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, were used; reflections from three of the four crystals were found to be reliably indexed throughout the data collection and were used in the structure determination. A total of four frames were collected at each temperature (300, 100, 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K), for data collection times ranging from 180 to 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min per frame. Each data frame contained information from eight of the eleven detectors (three were unavailable at the time of data collection), to give representative three-dimensional data sets containing 7533 (30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) and 6220 (100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) observed reflections. These were merged with values of <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">int</ce:inf> of 0.058 and 0.056 to give 1106 and 1230 unique strong reflections, respectively, and used to refine the structural model of 163 parameters including anisotropic ADPs. The limited data available at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (only 3318 observed reflections, merged with <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">int</ce:inf> of 0.075 to give 720 unique strong reflections) meant that a restrained refinement procedure was used, with the aim of allowing reliable Fourier maps to be calculated to confirm the X-ray results. Only the unit cell and atomic coordinates for the 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K model are supplied in the , and the results are used for confirmation of the X-ray findings only. Refinement was performed using SHELXL-97  on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> against all independent reflections by full-matrix least squares, using the known coordinates from the X-ray data (above). At 30 and 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, all hydrogen atoms had their positions and anisotropic atomic displacement parameters freely refined against the neutron data.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Neutron data were collected on the SXD instrument at the ISIS spallation neutron source , using the time-of-flight Laue diffraction method . This method uses a wavelength-sorted white neutron beam combined with large area position-sensitive detectors to allow a large volume of reciprocal space to be measured in a single crystal setting, or frame. The SXD instrument has 11 position-sensitive detectors giving a solid-angle coverage of over 2π Sr . The full data collection process consists of a series of frames collected with a stationary crystal-detector arrangement. To aid with data collection times and allow data to be accumulated at several temperatures from the rather small crystals available, a multiple crystal sample technique was employed , allowing a full data set to be collected in fewer frames (crystal orientations). In this example four single crystals, each of approximate dimension 1×1×1mm3, were used; reflections from three of the four crystals were found to be reliably indexed throughout the data collection and were used in the structure determination. A total of four frames were collected at each temperature (300, 100, 30K), for data collection times ranging from 180 to 600min per frame. Each data frame contained information from eight of the eleven detectors (three were unavailable at the time of data collection), to give representative three-dimensional data sets containing 7533 (30K) and 6220 (100K) observed reflections. These were merged with values of R int of 0.058 and 0.056 to give 1106 and 1230 unique strong reflections, respectively, and used to refine the structural model of 163 parameters including anisotropic ADPs. The limited data available at 300K (only 3318 observed reflections, merged with R int of 0.075 to give 720 unique strong reflections) meant that a restrained refinement procedure was used, with the aim of allowing reliable Fourier maps to be calculated to confirm the X-ray results. Only the unit cell and atomic coordinates for the 300K model are supplied in the , and the results are used for confirmation of the X-ray findings only. Refinement was performed using SHELXL-97  on F 2 against all independent reflections by full-matrix least squares, using the known coordinates from the X-ray data (above). At 30 and 100K, all hydrogen atoms had their positions and anisotropic atomic displacement parameters freely refined against the neutron data.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">A view of the asymmetric unit of the crystal structure at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (taken from the X-ray data) is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, and a summary of the refinement data is given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. All other refinement details are available in the . Details of the hydrogen bond geometry for all five refinements are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>. Difference Fourier sections were computed (without H1, the hydrogen atom involved in the hydrogen bond) on mean planes through C7, O1 and O2 and used only data to a maximum sin<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> value of 0.625<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Contoured maps were produced using the <ce:small-caps>mapview</ce:small-caps> program within WinGX  (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A view of the asymmetric unit of the crystal structure at 100K (taken from the X-ray data) is shown in  , and a summary of the refinement data is given in  . All other refinement details are available in the . Details of the hydrogen bond geometry for all five refinements are given in  . Difference Fourier sections were computed (without H1, the hydrogen atom involved in the hydrogen bond) on mean planes through C7, O1 and O2 and used only data to a maximum sin θ/λ value of 0.625Å-1. Contoured maps were produced using the mapview program within WinGX  ( ).

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The main findings of this structural study reflect the stability of the strong-to-medium hydrogen bond in the title compound under multiple temperature conditions. No significant difference is seen in the hydrogen bond geometry as the temperature is increased, and importantly the position and shape of the difference Fourier peak does not change ()—these Fourier images are known to be a sensitive indicator of any anomalous behaviour. In addition, there is no evidence for disorder of the hydrogen atom in the room temperature data, where this effect would be likely to be greatest. Full anisotropic refinement of the hydrogen atoms was possible with the low temperature neutron data, giving O–H bond lengths of 1.075(15) and 1.057(12)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å at 30 and 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively. Refinement of the fractional coordinates and an isotropic displacement parameter was possible for H1 for the X-ray data, giving O–H bond lengths of 0.81(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp> and 0.77(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å at 100 and 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively. The shortening of the X-ray bond lengths with respect to those determined in the neutron experiment is the usual effect of observing the electron density rather than the nuclear position. The fact that the neutron bond lengths do not increase with temperature reflects the invariance of this hydrogen bond, and the slight elongation of these with respect to the expected covalent O–H distance of around 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å reflects the relatively short, strong nature of this hydrogen bond. The bond lengths determined are all in agreement with the positions of the highest difference Fourier peaks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The main findings of this structural study reflect the stability of the strong-to-medium hydrogen bond in the title compound under multiple temperature conditions. No significant difference is seen in the hydrogen bond geometry as the temperature is increased, and importantly the position and shape of the difference Fourier peak does not change ()-these Fourier images are known to be a sensitive indicator of any anomalous behaviour. In addition, there is no evidence for disorder of the hydrogen atom in the room temperature data, where this effect would be likely to be greatest. Full anisotropic refinement of the hydrogen atoms was possible with the low temperature neutron data, giving O-H bond lengths of 1.075(15) and 1.057(12)Å at 30 and 100K, respectively. Refinement of the fractional coordinates and an isotropic displacement parameter was possible for H1 for the X-ray data, giving O-H bond lengths of 0.81(3) and 0.77(3)Å at 100 and 300K, respectively. The shortening of the X-ray bond lengths with respect to those determined in the neutron experiment is the usual effect of observing the electron density rather than the nuclear position. The fact that the neutron bond lengths do not increase with temperature reflects the invariance of this hydrogen bond, and the slight elongation of these with respect to the expected covalent O-H distance of around 1Å reflects the relatively short, strong nature of this hydrogen bond. The bond lengths determined are all in agreement with the positions of the highest difference Fourier peaks.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The results presented here for both the neutron and X-ray single crystal studies suggest that a fairly localised single potential well model (aSW-HB, using the nomenclature of Gilli et al. ) is the most appropriate description of the hydrogen bond in potassium hydrogen phthalate at temperatures up to room temperature. The practical effect of this is that, unlike other hydrogen bonds of a similar length and strength, a single structure determination at a single temperature would be enough to characterise the behaviour of the hydrogen atom.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The results presented here for both the neutron and X-ray single crystal studies suggest that a fairly localised single potential well model (aSW-HB, using the nomenclature of Gilli et al. ) is the most appropriate description of the hydrogen bond in potassium hydrogen phthalate at temperatures up to room temperature. The practical effect of this is that, unlike other hydrogen bonds of a similar length and strength, a single structure determination at a single temperature would be enough to characterise the behaviour of the hydrogen atom.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The asymmetry observed in the bond lengths of the carboxylic acid group (C7, O1 and O2) is entirely consistent with that expected . A degree of asymmetry is also observed in the bond lengths of the carboxylate group (C8, O3 and O4), with C8–O3 being significantly shorter than C8–O4. It is difficult, however, to draw any conclusions about the influence of the short hydrogen bond from this observation as each of these oxygen atoms has two interactions of less than 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å with a potassium ion; O3 has one longer interaction (2.9690(10)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å with K1) and two shorter interactions (2.6323(10) and 2.7519(12)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å with K1 related by symmetry operators [<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>+1/2, 1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>] and [2−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>−1/2], respectively), while O4 has two medium length interactions of 2.7776(10)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (K1) and 2.7928(11)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (K1 at [2−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>+1/2]). All distances are quoted from the 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K X-ray refinement. Separating the effect on the carboxylate group of these interactions from those of the valency within the short hydrogen bond is not possible from these data. The decrease in the X-ray bond lengths observed with temperature is due to librational shortening.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The asymmetry observed in the bond lengths of the carboxylic acid group (C7, O1 and O2) is entirely consistent with that expected . A degree of asymmetry is also observed in the bond lengths of the carboxylate group (C8, O3 and O4), with C8-O3 being significantly shorter than C8-O4. It is difficult, however, to draw any conclusions about the influence of the short hydrogen bond from this observation as each of these oxygen atoms has two interactions of less than 3Å with a potassium ion; O3 has one longer interaction (2.9690(10)Å with K1) and two shorter interactions (2.6323(10) and 2.7519(12)Å with K1 related by symmetry operators [x+1/2, 1-y, z] and [2-x, 1-y, z-1/2], respectively), while O4 has two medium length interactions of 2.7776(10)Å (K1) and 2.7928(11)Å (K1 at [2-x, 1-y, z+1/2]). All distances are quoted from the 100K X-ray refinement. Separating the effect on the carboxylate group of these interactions from those of the valency within the short hydrogen bond is not possible from these data. The decrease in the X-ray bond lengths observed with temperature is due to librational shortening.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Previous studies have shown that strong hydrogen bonds will frequently undergo changes in the position, vibrations or ordering of the hydrogen atom as temperature is increased. However, no evidence of this is observed for the short potassium hydrogen phthalate hydrogen bond between 30 and 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. We cannot of course discount the possibility that disorder is present at higher temperatures, but this seems unlikely in this system. Importantly, we have shown once again that X-ray diffraction is an important and efficient technique for screening such hydrogen-bonded molecular systems in which unexpected or anomalous behaviour may be present. It has previously been shown that X-ray diffraction  and combined X-ray and neutron diffraction  can identify and quantify these effects; what we have shown in this work is that easily accessible X-ray techniques can <ce:italic>eliminate</ce:italic> the possibility of anomalous or temperature-dependent behaviour being present in such hydrogen bonds (confirmed in this case by our accompanying neutron measurements). In the broader context of our work, this enables us to ensure that valuable neutron experiments are focused on systems with a proven need for these in fully defining the crucial hydrogen atom parameters.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Previous studies have shown that strong hydrogen bonds will frequently undergo changes in the position, vibrations or ordering of the hydrogen atom as temperature is increased. However, no evidence of this is observed for the short potassium hydrogen phthalate hydrogen bond between 30 and 300K. We cannot of course discount the possibility that disorder is present at higher temperatures, but this seems unlikely in this system. Importantly, we have shown once again that X-ray diffraction is an important and efficient technique for screening such hydrogen-bonded molecular systems in which unexpected or anomalous behaviour may be present. It has previously been shown that X-ray diffraction  and combined X-ray and neutron diffraction  can identify and quantify these effects; what we have shown in this work is that easily accessible X-ray techniques can eliminate the possibility of anomalous or temperature-dependent behaviour being present in such hydrogen bonds (confirmed in this case by our accompanying neutron measurements). In the broader context of our work, this enables us to ensure that valuable neutron experiments are focused on systems with a proven need for these in fully defining the crucial hydrogen atom parameters.

cln_elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The main findings of this structural study reflect the stability of the strong-to-medium hydrogen bond in the title compound under multiple temperature conditions. No significant difference is seen in the hydrogen bond geometry as the temperature is increased, and importantly the position and shape of the difference Fourier peak does not change ()—these Fourier images are known to be a sensitive indicator of any anomalous behaviour. In addition, there is no evidence for disorder of the hydrogen atom in the room temperature data, where this effect would be likely to be greatest. Full anisotropic refinement of the hydrogen atoms was possible with the low temperature neutron data, giving O–H bond lengths of 1.075(15) and 1.057(12)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å at 30 and 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively. Refinement of the fractional coordinates and an isotropic displacement parameter was possible for H1 for the X-ray data, giving O–H bond lengths of 0.81(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp> and 0.77(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å at 100 and 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively. The shortening of the X-ray bond lengths with respect to those determined in the neutron experiment is the usual effect of observing the electron density rather than the nuclear position. The fact that the neutron bond lengths do not increase with temperature reflects the invariance of this hydrogen bond, and the slight elongation of these with respect to the expected covalent O–H distance of around 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å reflects the relatively short, strong nature of this hydrogen bond. The bond lengths determined are all in agreement with the positions of the highest difference Fourier peaks.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The main findings of this structural study reflect the stability of the strong-to-medium hydrogen bond in the title compound under multiple temperature conditions. No significant difference is seen in the hydrogen bond geometry as the temperature is increased, and importantly the position and shape of the difference Fourier peak does not change ()-these Fourier images are known to be a sensitive indicator of any anomalous behaviour. In addition, there is no evidence for disorder of the hydrogen atom in the room temperature data, where this effect would be likely to be greatest. Full anisotropic refinement of the hydrogen atoms was possible with the low temperature neutron data, giving O-H bond lengths of 1.075(15) and 1.057(12)Å at 30 and 100K, respectively. Refinement of the fractional coordinates and an isotropic displacement parameter was possible for H1 for the X-ray data, giving O-H bond lengths of 0.81(3) and 0.77(3)Å at 100 and 300K, respectively. The shortening of the X-ray bond lengths with respect to those determined in the neutron experiment is the usual effect of observing the electron density rather than the nuclear position. The fact that the neutron bond lengths do not increase with temperature reflects the invariance of this hydrogen bond, and the slight elongation of these with respect to the expected covalent O-H distance of around 1Å reflects the relatively short, strong nature of this hydrogen bond. The bond lengths determined are all in agreement with the positions of the highest difference Fourier peaks.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">The asymmetric unit of KHP taken from the 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K X-ray refinement, showing the links to symmetry related atoms, with ellipsoids shown at the 30% level. Symmetry operators are: (A) [1.5−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>−0.5], (B) [2−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>−0.5], (C) [2−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>+0.5], (D) [0.5+<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>+1, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>+0.5].</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  The asymmetric unit of KHP taken from the 100K X-ray refinement, showing the links to symmetry related atoms, with ellipsoids shown at the 30% level. Symmetry operators are: (A) [1.5-x, y, z-0.5], (B) [2-x, 1-y, z-0.5], (C) [2-x, 1-y, z+0.5], (D) [0.5+x, y+1, z+0.5].

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Difference Fourier maps (<ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">o</ce:inf>−<ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf>) obtained with both neutron (right) and X-ray diffraction (left). The maps were calculated on a plane through atoms C7, O1 and O4 (related by symmetry operator). Note that hydrogen peaks are negative in neutron diffraction.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  Difference Fourier maps (F o-F c) obtained with both neutron (right) and X-ray diffraction (left). The maps were calculated on a plane through atoms C7, O1 and O4 (related by symmetry operator). Note that hydrogen peaks are negative in neutron diffraction.
